verses.text: Joash was seven years old when he became king, and he reigned forty years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Zibiah, from Beersheba.
verses.comment: Age and reign length match the Hebrew; Zibiah’s name is interpreted directly.

verses.text: Joash did what was right in the eyes of the LORD all the days of Jehoiada the priest.
verses.comment: Phrase matches the standard; Hebrew supports specifying 'all the days of Jehoiada.'

verses.text: Jehoiada took two wives for him, and he had sons and daughters.
verses.comment: Clear statement; note that Jehoiada arranged his marriages.

verses.text: Afterward, Joash decided to restore the house of the LORD.
verses.comment: ‘Decided’ reflects ‘set his heart’; direct phrasing for clarity.

verses.text: He gathered the priests and Levites together, and said to them, “Go to the cities of Judah and collect money from all Israel to repair the temple of your God every year. Be sure to act quickly.” But the Levites did not hurry.
verses.comment: ‘Collect money’ conveys ‘bring in from all Israel money to repair’; ‘Levites did not hurry’ is literal.

verses.text: So the king called Jehoiada the chief and said to him, “Why have you not required the Levites to bring in from Judah and Jerusalem the tax set by Moses the servant of the LORD, and by the congregation of Israel, for the tent of the testimony?”
verses.comment: ‘Tax set by Moses’ = offering required by Law. ‘Tent of the testimony’ = tabernacle.

verses.text: For the sons of Athaliah, that wicked woman, had broken into the house of God and used all the dedicated things of the house of the LORD for the Baals.
verses.comment: ‘That wicked woman’ straightforward from Hebrew; ‘Baals’ plural.

verses.text: So the king commanded, and they made a chest and set it outside the gate of the house of the LORD.
verses.comment: Literal rendering; location clarified as ‘outside the gate.’

verses.text: And they made a proclamation throughout Judah and Jerusalem to bring to the LORD the tax that Moses the servant of God had laid on Israel in the wilderness.
verses.comment: ‘Tax’ delivered in plain terms for clarity.

verses.text: All the officials and all the people rejoiced and brought their offerings and dropped them into the chest until it was full.
verses.comment: ‘Dropped offerings’ conveys literal sense of bringing and putting in.

verses.text: Whenever the chest was brought by the Levites to the king’s officers, and when they saw there was much money, the king’s secretary and the high priest’s officer would come and empty the chest, then carry it back to its place. They did this regularly and collected a great amount of money.
verses.comment: ‘King’s secretary and high priest’s officer’—direct from Hebrew titles.

verses.text: And the king and Jehoiada gave the collected money to those who did the work of repairing the LORD’s house. They hired masons and carpenters to restore the LORD’s house, and also iron and bronze workers to repair the house of the LORD.
verses.comment: Specific trades named as in original Hebrew.

verses.text: The workmen labored, and the restoration progressed under their hands. They restored God’s house to its proper condition and strengthened it.
verses.comment: ‘Strengthened it’ reflects Hebrew, meaning ‘made it firm.’

verses.text: When they finished, they brought the rest of the money before the king and Jehoiada, and with it they made vessels for the house of the LORD—utensils for serving and for offering, and bowls, and gold and silver articles. They offered burnt offerings continually in the house of the LORD all the days of Jehoiada.
verses.comment: Collates all items made from Hebrew list; ‘offered burnt offerings continually’ is faithful.

verses.text: Jehoiada grew old and died, full of days. He was one hundred and thirty years old when he died.
verses.comment: Literal age; ‘full of days’ is a Hebrew idiom for a long life.

verses.text: They buried him in the city of David among the kings, because he had done good in Israel and toward God and his house.
verses.comment: ‘Among the kings’ stated literally from the text.

verses.text: After Jehoiada’s death, the leaders of Judah came and bowed down to the king. Then the king listened to them.
verses.comment: Direct action; ‘bowed down’ translates Hebrew ‘prostrated themselves.’

verses.text: And they abandoned the house of the LORD, the God of their ancestors, and served Asherim and idols. Then wrath came upon Judah and Jerusalem because of their guilt.
verses.comment: ‘Asherim’ plural; ‘idols’ based on context of Hebrew; ‘guilt’ is ‘culpability.’

verses.text: Yet the LORD sent prophets to them to bring them back to him. The prophets testified against them, but they would not listen.
verses.comment: ‘Testified against’ is direct from Hebrew root.

verses.text: Then the Spirit of God came upon Zechariah the son of Jehoiada the priest. He stood above the people and said to them, “Thus says God: Why do you break the LORD’s commandments so that you cannot prosper? Because you have forsaken the LORD, he has forsaken you.”
verses.comment: ‘Stood above’ mirrors ‘stood over’; ‘forsaken’ picked for accuracy.

verses.text: But they conspired against him and stoned him with stones by order of the king in the courtyard of the house of the LORD.
verses.comment: ‘By order of the king in the courtyard’ rendered directly from Hebrew.

verses.text: Thus King Joash did not remember the kindness that Jehoiada, Zechariah’s father, had shown him, but killed his son. As he died, Zechariah said, “May the LORD see and avenge!”
verses.comment: ‘Kindness’ as ‘steadfast love’; Zechariah’s cry literal.

verses.text: At the turn of the year, the army of Aram came against Joash and invaded Judah and Jerusalem. They killed all the officials of the people and sent all the spoils they took to the king of Damascus.
verses.comment: ‘Turn of the year’ is the Hebrew idiom; ‘spoils’ is equivalent to ‘plunder.’

verses.text: Even though the army of Aram was small, the LORD delivered a very great army into their hand, because Judah had forsaken the LORD, the God of their ancestors. Thus they executed judgment on Joash.
verses.comment: ‘Army was small ... delivered great army’—literal meaning; ‘executed judgment’ for idiom.

verses.text: When the Arameans withdrew from him—for they left him severely wounded—his own servants conspired against him because of the blood of the sons of Jehoiada the priest, and killed him on his bed. So he died, and they buried him in the city of David, but not in the tombs of the kings.
verses.comment: ‘Severely wounded’ best for clarity; ‘sons of Jehoiada’—some texts read singular.

verses.text: Those who conspired against him were Zabad son of Shimeath the Ammonite, and Jehozabad son of Shimrith the Moabite.
verses.comment: Names match Hebrew; mothers’ ethnicities specified for clarity.

verses.text: The account of Joash’s sons, the many oracles spoken against him, and the restoration of the house of God are written in the commentary on the Book of the Kings. Amaziah his son succeeded him as king.
verses.comment: ‘Commentary on the Book of the Kings’ renders Hebrew ‘midrash’; closing phrase matches the succession format.
